Chapter 2.2:1: The Lord says, The people of Moab have sinned again and again, and for this I will certainly punish them. They dishonored the bones of the king of Edom by burning them to ashes.

Chapter 2.2:2: I will send fire upon the land of Moab and burn down the fortresses of Kerioth. The people of Moab will die in the noise of battle while soldiers are shouting and trumpets are sounding.

Chapter 2.2:3: I will kill the ruler of Moab and all the leaders of the land.

Chapter 2.2:4: The Lord says, The people of Judah have sinned again and again, and for this I will certainly punish them. They have despised my teachings and have not kept my commands. They have been led astray by the same false gods that their ancestors served.

Chapter 2.2:5: So I will send fire upon Judah and burn down the fortresses of Jerusalem.

Chapter 2.2:6: The Lord says, The people of Israel have sinned again and again, and for this I will certainly punish them. They sell into slavery honest people who cannot pay their debts, the poor who cannot repay even the price of a pair of sandals.

Chapter 2.2:7: They trample down the weak and helpless and push the poor out of the way. A man and his father have intercourse with the same slave woman, and so profane my holy name.

Chapter 2.2:8: At every place of worship people sleep on clothing that they have taken from the poor as security for debts. In the temple of their God they drink wine which they have taken from those who owe them money.

Chapter 2.2:9: And yet, my people, it was for your sake that I totally destroyed the Amorites, who were as tall as cedar trees and as strong as oaks.

Chapter 2.2:10: I brought you out of Egypt, led you through the desert for forty years, and gave you the land of the Amorites to be your own.

Chapter 2.2:11: I chose some of your sons to be prophets and some of your young men to be nazirites. Isn't this true, people of Israel? I, the Lord, have spoken.

Chapter 2.2:12: But you made the nazirites drink wine, and ordered the prophets not to speak my message.

Chapter 2.2:13: And now I will crush you to the ground, and you will groan like a cart loaded with grain.

Chapter 2.2:14: Not even fast runners will escape; strong men will lose their strength, and soldiers will not be able to save their own lives.

Chapter 2.2:15: Archers will not stand their ground, fast runners will not get away, and men on horses will not escape with their lives.

Chapter 2.2:16: On that day even the bravest soldiers will drop their weapons and run. The Lord has spoken.

Chapter 3.3:1: People of Israel, listen to this message which the Lord has spoken about you, the entire nation that he brought out of Egypt:

Chapter 3.3:2: Of all the nations on earth, you are the only one I have known and cared for. That is what makes your sins so terrible, and that is why I must punish you for them.

Chapter 3.3:3: Do two people start traveling together without arranging to meet?

Chapter 3.3:4: Does a lion roar in the forest unless he has found a victim? Does a young lion growl in his den unless he has caught something?

Chapter 3.3:5: Does a bird get caught in a trap if the trap has not been baited? Does a trap spring unless something sets it off?

Chapter 3.3:6: Does the war trumpet sound in a city without making the people afraid? Does disaster strike a city unless the Lord sends it?

Chapter 3.3:7: The Sovereign Lord never does anything without revealing his plan to his servants, the prophets.

Chapter 3.3:8: When a lion roars, who can keep from being afraid? When the Sovereign Lord speaks, who can keep from proclaiming his message?

Chapter 3.3:9: Announce to those who live in the palaces of Egypt and Ashdod: Gather together in the hills around Samaria and see the great disorder and the crimes being committed there.

Chapter 3.3:10: The Lord says, These people fill their mansions with things taken by crime and violence. They don't even know how to be honest.

Chapter 3.3:11: And so an enemy will surround their land, destroy their defenses, and plunder their mansions.

Chapter 3.3:12: The Lord says, As a shepherd recovers only two legs or an ear of a sheep that a lion has eaten, so only a few will survive of Samaria's people, who now recline on luxurious couches.

Chapter 3.3:13: Listen now, and warn the descendants of Jacob, says the Sovereign Lord Almighty.

Chapter 3.3:14: On the day when I punish the people of Israel for their sins, I will destroy the altars of Bethel. The corners of every altar will be broken off and will fall to the ground.

Chapter 3.3:15: I will destroy winter houses and summer houses. The houses decorated with ivory will fall in ruins; every large house will be destroyed.

Chapter 6.6:1: How terrible it will be for you that have such an easy life in Zion and for you that feel safe in Samariaâ€”you great leaders of this great nation Israel, you to whom the people go for help!

Chapter 6.6:2: Go and look at the city of Calneh. Then go on to the great city of Hamath and on down to the Philistine city of Gath. Were they any better than the kingdoms of Judah and Israel? Was their territory larger than yours?

Chapter 6.6:3: You refuse to admit that a day of disaster is coming, but what you do only brings that day closer.

Chapter 6.6:4: How terrible it will be for you that stretch out on your luxurious couches, feasting on veal and lamb!

Chapter 6.6:5: You like to compose songs, as David did, and play them on harps.

Chapter 6.6:6: You drink wine by the bowlful and use the finest perfumes, but you do not mourn over the ruin of Israel.

Chapter 6.6:7: So you will be the first to go into exile. Your feasts and banquets will come to an end.

Chapter 6.6:8: The Sovereign Lord Almighty has given this solemn warning: I hate the pride of the people of Israel; I despise their luxurious mansions. I will give their capital city and everything in it to the enemy.

Chapter 6.6:9: If there are ten men left in a family, they will die.

Chapter 6.6:10: The dead man's relative, the one in charge of the funeral, will take the body out of the house. The relative will call to whoever is still left in the house, Is anyone else there with you? The person will answer, No! Then the relative will say, Be quiet! We must be careful not even to mention the Lord's name.

Chapter 6.6:11: When the Lord gives the command, houses large and small will be smashed to pieces.

Chapter 6.6:12: Do horses gallop on rocks? Does anyone plow the sea with oxen? Yet you have turned justice into poison, and right into wrong.

Chapter 6.6:13: You brag about capturing the town of Lodebar. You boast, We were strong enough to take Karnaim.

Chapter 6.6:14: The Lord God Almighty himself says, People of Israel, I am going to send a foreign army to occupy your country. It will oppress you from Hamath Pass in the north to the Brook of the Arabah in the south.

Chapter 7.7:1: I had a vision from the Sovereign Lord. In it I saw him create a swarm of locusts just after the king's share of the hay had been cut and the grass was starting to grow again.

Chapter 7.7:2: In my vision I saw the locusts eat up every green thing in the land, and then I said, Sovereign Lord, forgive your people! How can they survive? They are so small and weak!

Chapter 7.7:3: The Lord changed his mind and said, What you saw will not take place.

Chapter 7.7:4: I had another vision from the Sovereign Lord. In it I saw him preparing to punish his people with fire. The fire burned up the great ocean under the earth and started to burn up the land.

Chapter 7.7:5: Then I said, Stop, O Sovereign Lord! How can your people survive? They are so small and weak!

Chapter 7.7:6: The Lord changed his mind again and said, This will not take place either.

Chapter 7.7:7: I had another vision from the Lord. In it I saw him standing beside a wall that had been built with the use of a plumb line, and there was a plumb line in his hand.

Chapter 7.7:8: He asked me, Amos, what do you see? A plumb line, I answered. Then he said, I am using it to show that my people are like a wall that is out of line. I will not change my mind again about punishing them.

Chapter 7.7:9: The places where Isaac's descendants worship will be destroyed. The holy places of Israel will be left in ruins. I will bring the dynasty of King Jeroboam to an end.

Chapter 7.7:10: Amaziah, the priest of Bethel, then sent a report to King Jeroboam of Israel: Amos is plotting against you among the people. His speeches will destroy the country.

Chapter 7.7:11: This is what he says: Jeroboam will die in battle, and the people of Israel will be taken away from their land into exile.

Chapter 7.7:12: Amaziah then said to Amos, That's enough, prophet! Go on back to Judah and do your preaching there. Let them pay you for it.

Chapter 7.7:13: Don't prophesy here at Bethel any more. This is the king's place of worship, the national temple.

Chapter 7.7:14: Amos answered, I am not the kind of prophet who prophesies for pay. I am a herdsman, and I take care of fig trees.

Chapter 7.7:15: But the Lord took me from my work as a shepherd and ordered me to come and prophesy to his people Israel.

Chapter 7.7:16: So now listen to what the Lord says. You tell me to stop prophesying, to stop raving against the people of Israel.

Chapter 7.7:17: And so, Amaziah, the Lord says to you, Your wife will become a prostitute in the city, and your children will be killed in war. Your land will be divided up and given to others, and you yourself will die in a heathen country. And the people of Israel will certainly be taken away from their own land into exile.

Chapter 8.8:1: I had another vision from the Sovereign Lord. In it I saw a basket of fruit.

Chapter 8.8:2: The Lord asked, Amos, what do you see? A basket of fruit, I answered. The Lord said to me, The end has come for my people Israel. I will not change my mind again about punishing them.

Chapter 8.8:3: On that day the songs in the palace will become cries of mourning. There will be dead bodies everywhere. They will be cast out in silence.

Chapter 8.8:4: Listen to this, you that trample on the needy and try to destroy the poor of the country.

Chapter 8.8:5: You say to yourselves, We can hardly wait for the holy days to be over so that we can sell our grain. When will the Sabbath end, so that we can start selling again? Then we can overcharge, use false measures, and fix the scales to cheat our customers.

Chapter 8.8:6: We can sell worthless wheat at a high price. We'll find someone poor who can't pay his debts, not even the price of a pair of sandals, and we'll buy him as a slave.

Chapter 8.8:7: The Lord, the God of Israel, has sworn, I will never forget their evil deeds.

Chapter 8.8:8: And so the earth will quake, and everyone in the land will be in distress. The whole country will be shaken; it will rise and fall like the Nile River.

Chapter 8.8:9: The time is coming when I will make the sun go down at noon and the earth grow dark in daytime. I, the Sovereign Lord, have spoken.

Chapter 8.8:10: I will turn your festivals into funerals and change your glad songs into cries of grief. I will make you shave your heads and wear sackcloth, and you will be like parents mourning for their only child. That day will be bitter to the end.

Chapter 8.8:11: The time is coming when I will send famine on the land. People will be hungry, but not for bread; they will be thirsty, but not for water. They will hunger and thirst for a message from the Lord. I, the Sovereign Lord, have spoken.

Chapter 8.8:12: People will wander from the Dead Sea to the Mediterranean and then on around from the north to the east. They will look everywhere for a message from the Lord, but they will not find it.

Chapter 8.8:13: On that day even healthy young men and women will collapse from thirst.

Chapter 8.8:14: Those who swear by the idols of Samaria, who say, By the god of Dan or By the god of Beershebaâ€”those people will fall and not rise again.
